title: Quiz 4: Community Health Nursing - August 2021 FQE
description: Complete Final Qualifying Examination from August 2021 covering Community Health, Epidemiology, Management, and Communicable Diseases.

questions.question: Contraceptive methods used by breastfeeding mothers include:

options.text: Oestrogen free pills and copper T IUCD
Combined oral contraceptives and hormonal IUD

questions.explanation: Breastfeeding mothers should avoid estrogen-containing contraceptives (like COCs) as they can diminish milk supply. Progestin-only pills and Copper T IUCD are safe.

questions.question: The steps followed in community dialogue are:

options.text: Problem identification, problem analysis, identification of best options, prioritization of options
Prioritization of options, identification of the best options, problem identification, problem analysis
Problem identification, identification of the best options, problem analysis, prioritization of options
Problem identification, problem analysis, prioritization of options, identification of best options

questions.explanation: The logical flow is: Identify -> Analyze -> Find Options -> Prioritize.
questions.hint: Start with identification, end with prioritizing.

questions.question: Ground water includes:
questions.explanation: Ground water comes from aquifers (wells/springs). Rivers and ponds are surface water.

questions.question: Childhood viral immunizable diseases include:
questions.explanation: Measles and Hepatitis B are viral. Note: Haemophilus influenzae is bacterial, but this option set is the best fit in the context of typical exam questions distinguishing from sets of purely bacterial diseases like Option C.
questions.hint: Look for Measles and Hep B.

questions.question: The use of surveillance data include:

options.text: Facilitation of planning and stimulating dissemination
Detecting changes in health practice and detection of epidemics
Estimates workload of health workers and evaluating control and prevention measures
Monitoring change in accessibility of health facilities, estimates health problem

questions.explanation: The primary purpose of surveillance is to detect epidemics (sudden changes) and trends.

questions.question: Nursing care based on the needs of the people is determined by:
questions.explanation: Community diagnosis is the systematic process of assessing needs to plan care.

questions.question: Income generating projects often fail to meet expectations and sometimes end abruptly due to:

options.text: Lack of donors and poor networking
Lack of careful planning and poor networking
Illiteracy and lack of careful planning

questions.explanation: Sustainability depends on planning and networking (market linkages), not just donors.

questions.question: The overall goal of community diagnosis is for:

options.text: Collection of information on the available resources
The community to point out where health services should be utilized
The collection of health information regarding utilization
Health workers together with the community members to identify health problems affecting the community

questions.explanation: It is a participatory process for identifying and prioritizing problems.

questions.question: The sustainable development goal (SDG) number 3 is geared to:

options.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages

questions.explanation: SDG 3 is Good Health and Well-being.

questions.question: A patient is said to be multi-drug resistant for tuberculosis if he does not respond to:

options.text: One or two drugs excluding isoniazid and ethambutol

questions.explanation: MDR-TB is resistance to at least Isoniazid and Rifampicin.
questions.hint: The two most powerful first-line drugs.

questions.question: The family planning method that comprise symptom-thermal natural family planning is a combination of:

options.text: Cervical mucus and basal body temperature

questions.explanation: Symptothermal method combines temperature (Thermal) and mucus signs (Symptom).

questions.question: The nursing officer in charge of MCH/FP should maintain accurate records of the clinic activities so as to provide:

options.text: Data to justify the need for continuing education
Reliable indicators on the state of health of the community

questions.explanation: Accurate records yield health indicators (coverage, disease rates) reflecting community health status.

questions.question: Procurement plan supplies management means:

options.text: Monitoring and evaluating of all aspects of procurement
Planning and supervision of procurement for all activities
Annual document detailing all the procurement requirements necessary to perform the planned activities
Specifications on the aspects of procurement process

questions.explanation: A procurement plan is an annual document listing what needs to be bought to support activities.

questions.question: Problem solving technique has the following sequence:

options.text: Problem identification, goal setting, problem exploration
Problem identification, problem exploration, goal setting
Problem identification, look at alternatives, goal setting
Problem identification, goal setting, look at alternatives

questions.explanation: Identify Problem -> Set Goal -> Explore Alternatives -> Select/Act.

questions.question: The primary health care elements that Kenya added to the Alma Ata declaration are:
questions.explanation: Kenya added Mental Health and Dental Health to the original 8 elements.

questions.question: A probing question is:

options.text: One that requires information about a sensitive or deeply personal issue
One that encourages the interviewee to say more about a topic
One that asks indirectly about people's opinions
One that moves the conversation on to another topic

questions.explanation: Probing encourages deeper elaboration (e.g., 'Tell me more').

questions.question: The principles of primary health care (PHC) include:
questions.explanation: Equitable distribution is a fundamental principle. (Note: Option B and C also contain principles, but 'Equitable distribution' is often cited first).

questions.question: The best approach to introduce the use of pit latrines in a place where open defecation is highly practiced is by:

options.text: Asking the local administration to enforce digging
Working with and talking to people on how to use pit latrines
Digging latrines for each household through donor funding

questions.explanation: Community engagement and education are more effective for behavior change than enforcement or free provision.

questions.question: Temporary hardness of water is caused by presence of:
questions.explanation: Bicarbonates cause temporary hardness (removed by boiling). Sulfates/Chlorides cause permanent hardness.

questions.question: The type of immunity which occurs after an infection is:
questions.explanation: Recovering from an infection generates Natural Active immunity.

questions.question: In chemical sterilization, instruments should be immersed in glutaraldehyde such as cidex for:
questions.explanation: Sterilization (killing spores) requires 10 hours soaking in glutaraldehyde.

questions.question: Incidence rate measures:

options.text: All cases of a disease present in the population at a specified time
New cases of a disease occurring in the population
Number of persons in the population at risk of a disease
Changes occurring in the disease pattern

questions.explanation: Incidence = New cases.

questions.question: Sustainable community development is ensured by:
questions.explanation: Participation leads to ownership, which ensures sustainability.

questions.question: The main implementers of PHC in the community are:
questions.explanation: CHWs/CHVs are the frontline implementers at the community level.

questions.question: According to Sigmund Freud, the super ego is concerned with:
questions.explanation: The Superego represents morality and conscience.

questions.question: Stratification of society into class system was theorized by:
questions.explanation: Karl Marx theorized class stratification based on economic relations.

questions.question: Principles of communicable diseases are:

options.text: Attacking the source, immunity, interrupting the rout of transmission
Attacking the source, interrupting the route of transmission, protecting the host
Protecting the host, attacking the source, mass treatment
Interrupting the route of transmission, carrying out surveys, protecting the host

questions.explanation: The principles target the Chain of Infection: Source, Transmission, Host.

questions.question: Dietary sources for vitamin D include:
questions.explanation: Liver and egg yolk are classic sources. Fatty fish is also a source, but Option C is the standard exam answer.

questions.question: Measures of dispersion include:
questions.explanation: Range measures the spread (dispersion) of data.

questions.question: The priority in management of cholera patients during an epidemic is:

options.text: Referral of the patient to the hospital

questions.explanation: Rehydration is the immediate priority to prevent death from shock.

questions.question: What is community dialogue?

options.text: A process by which the communities are actively involved in all stages of project or program implementation
Method of communication involving two or more parties in solving a problem
Recognizing the warning signs during pregnancy and child birth
The inter-connectedness which equally applies to the other cohorts in human life

questions.explanation: Community dialogue enables active community involvement in problem solving.

questions.question: One of the following mortality rates uses the estimated total mid-year population as its denominator:
questions.explanation: Crude rates use the total population.

questions.question: The following study design is most suitable for studying rare exposures of a health condition:
questions.explanation: Cohort studies recruit based on exposure, making them ideal for rare exposures.

questions.question: In 2011, 199 confirmed cases of meningococcal meningitis occurred in Nyanza... There were 20 deaths. What was the case fatality rate?
questions.explanation: CFR = (Deaths / Cases) * 100 = (20/199) * 100 approx 10%.

questions.question: Airborne diseases include:

options.text: Measles, whooping cough, mumps, chicken pox
Mumps, tetanus, chicken pox, yellow fever
Whooping cough, tuberculosis, yellow fever, poliomyelitis

questions.explanation: Option A lists diseases all transmitted via respiratory droplets/air.

questions.question: In the treatment of tuberculosis, DOT means:

options.text: Patient getting tuberculosis treatment as close to home as possible
Patient adheres to treatment during the intensive phase
Directly observed therapy with weekly monitoring

questions.explanation: DOT = Directly Observed Treatment.

questions.question: The members of school health program include:

options.text: Pupils, parents, sub-county medical officer, teachers
Teachers, sub-county public nurse, sub-county medical officer
Health center staff, sub-county public health nurse

questions.explanation: Primary stakeholders are pupils, parents, teachers, and community leaders.

questions.question: The 3rd stage of team formation is:
questions.explanation: Tuckman's stages: Forming -> Storming -> Norming -> Performing.

questions.question: The head of a sub-county health management team is:
questions.explanation: The SCMOH heads the SCHMT.

questions.question: A patriarchal society is one where:

options.text: Women occupy the high rank in leadership
Men and women enjoy equal rights and freedom
Women's roles are exclusively defined in terms of house hold management and matrimonial duties
There is a democratic arrangement to distribute ranks in leadership

questions.explanation: Patriarchy involves male dominance and restricted roles for women.

questions.question: Select the characteristics of democratic type of leadership: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Democratic leadership involves participation, feedback, and empowerment.

questions.question: Identify risk factors for Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) infection: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risks include sexual behavior factors and smoking.

questions.question: What are the major causes of resistance to change? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Resistance stems from fear, lack of info, and self-interest.

questions.question: Roles of the sub-county public health nurse include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The SCPHN manages, coordinates, and supervises nursing services.

questions.question: Non-contraceptive benefits of Combined Oral Contraceptives (COCs) include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: COCs help with cycle issues and reduce certain cancer risks, but do not protect against HIV.

questions.question: Importance of meal planning involves: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Planning saves resources (time, money) and improves health.

questions.question: Arrange Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs from the Base to the Top:
questions.explanation: Hierarchy: Physiological -> Safety -> Love -> Esteem -> Self-Actualization.

questions.question: Factors increasing transmission of contact diseases include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Contact diseases spread via proximity, hygiene failure, and fomites.

questions.question: Select the correct transmission cycles of Yellow Fever: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The three cycles are Jungle, Savannah, and Urban.
